messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 46 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: FloorSet - a VLSI Floorplanning Dataset with Design Constraints of Real-World SoCs

Paper Abstract: Abstract. Floorplanning for systems-on-a-chip (SoCs) and its sub-systems is a crucial and non-trivial step of the physical design flow. It represents a difficult combinatorial optimization problem. A typical large scale SoC with 120 partitions generates a search-space of âˆ¼10250similar-toabsentsuperscript10250\sim 10^{250}. As novel machine learning (ML) approaches emerge to tackle such problems, there is a growing need for a modern benchmark that comprises a large training dataset and performance metrics that better reflect real-world constraints and objectives compared to existing benchmarks. To address this need, we present ğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğšğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğš\mathtt{FloorSet} - two comprehensive datasets of synthetic fixed-outline floorplan layouts that reflect the distribution of real SoCs. Each dataset has 1â€‹M1ğ‘€1M training samples and 100100100 test samples where each sample is a synthetic floorplan. ğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğšğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğš\mathtt{FloorSet}-Prime comprises fully-abutted rectilinear partitions and near-optimal wire-length. A simplified dataset that reflects early design phases, ğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğšğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğš\mathtt{FloorSet}-Lite comprises rectangular partitions, with <5%absentpercent5<5\% white-space and near-optimal wire-length. Both datasets define hard constraints seen in modern design flows such as shape constraints, edge-affinity, grouping constraints, and pre-placement constraints. ğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğšğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğš\mathtt{FloorSet} is intended to spur fundamental research on large-scale constrained optimization problems. Crucially, ğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğšğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğš\mathtt{FloorSet} alleviates the core issue of reproducibility in modern ML driven solutions to such problems. ğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğšğ™µğš•ğš˜ğš˜ğš›ğš‚ğšğš\mathtt{FloorSet} is available as an open-source repository for the research community111https://anonymous.4open.science/r/Constrained_Floorplans_Dataset-D490/.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 46 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 46"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Fixed-outline floorplanning through better local search",
        "Fixed-outline floorplanning: enabling hierarchical design",
        "VLSI Placement Parameter Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning",
        "Generalizable Floorplanner through Corner Block List Representation and Hypergraph Embedding",
        "Chip-Chat: Challenges and Opportunities in Conversational Hardware Design",
        "Bookshelf",
        "ISPD 2015 Benchmarks with Fence Regions and Routing Blockages for Detailed-Routing-Driven Placement",
        "Machine Learning in Computational Lithography",
        "Modern floorplanning based on B/sup */-tree and fast simulated annealing",
        "DAGSizer: A Directed Graph Convolutional Network Approach to Discrete Gate Sizing of VLSI Graphs",
        "PROBE2.0: A Systematic Framework for Routability Assessment From Technology to Design in Advanced Nodes",
        "Template-based PDN Synthesis in Floorplan and Placement Using Classifier and CNN Techniques",
        "ICCAD-2017 CAD contest in multi-deck standard cell legalization and benchmarks",
        "Fault Detection based on Deep Learning for Digital VLSI Circuits",
        "GSRC",
        "Circuit Training: An open-source framework for generating chip floor plans with distributed deep reinforcement learning.",
        "A timing engine inspired graph neural network model for pre-routing slack prediction",
        "Eyecharts: Constructive benchmarking of gate sizing heuristics",
        "Deep Learning for Logic Optimization Algorithms",
        "A deep learning methodology to proliferate golden signoff timing",
        "Learn to Floorplan through Acquisition of Effective Local Search Heuristics",
        "ISPD-IBM",
        "IWLS 2005",
        "Machine Learning for CAD/EDA: The Road Ahead",
        "â€œUnobserved Cornerâ€ Prediction: Reducing Timing Analysis Effort for Faster Design Convergence in Advanced-Node Design",
        "Construction of Realistic Place-and-Route Benchmarks for Machine Learning Applications",
        "Transfer Learning for Design-Space Exploration with High-Level Synthesis",
        "ChiPFormer: Transferable Chip Placement via Offline Decision Transformer",
        "MaskPlace: Fast Chip Placement via Reinforced Visual Representation Learning",
        "DRC Hotspot Prediction at Sub-10nm Process Nodes Using Customized Convolutional Network",
        "A Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach for Global Routing",
        "A test vector selection method based on machine learning for efficient presilicon verification",
        "ChipNeMo: Domain-Adapted LLMs for Chip Design",
        "GraphPlanner: Floorplanning with Graph Neural Network",
        "GAN-CTS: A Generative Adversarial Framework for Clock Tree Prediction and Optimization",
        "RL-Sizer: VLSI Gate Sizing for Timing Optimization using Deep Reinforcement Learning",
        "ISPD 2018 Initial Detailed Routing Contest and Benchmarks",
        "MCNC",
        "LSOracle: a Logic Synthesis Framework Driven by Artificial Intelligence: Invited Paper",
        "OpenCores",
        "The ISPD-2012 discrete cell sizing contest and benchmark suite",
        "Closing the Virtuous Cycle of AI for IC and IC for AI",
        "MLCAD: A Survey of Research in Machine Learning for CAD Keynote Paper",
        "Learning from the Past: Efficient High-level Synthesis Design Space Exploration for FPGAs",
        "GoodFloorplan: Graph Convolutional Network and Reinforcement Learning-Based Floorplanning",
        "Online 3D Bin Packing with Constrained Deep Reinforcement Learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 46 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in FloorSet - a VLSI Floorplanning Dataset with Design Constraints of Real-World SoCs, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
